content: The Act titled "Proven Programs for the Future of Education Act of 2007" introduces research-proven programs and competitive grants in the field of education. It includes provisions for formula grants to state educational agencies, state grant applications, information dissemination, and defines research-proven programs. The Act introduces research-proven programs and competitive grants in education. Competitive preference points may be awarded to agencies proposing to use research-proven programs. It also amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act to include research-proven reading programs. Formula grants to state educational agencies are outlined. Section 1202 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to include competitive preference points for using research-proven reading programs in subgrants to local educational agencies. The Act emphasizes the importance of research-proven programs in education. In amending Section 1202 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, competitive preference points are added for utilizing research-proven reading programs in subgrants to local educational agencies. The emphasis is on the importance of research-proven programs in education. SEC. 203. STATE FORMULA GRANT APPLICATIONS. SEC. 204 amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to prioritize research-proven reading programs. It includes inserting references to these programs in paragraph (1) and (3) of Section 1207(a). Section 1208 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to include a definition of a research-proven reading program, which must meet specific criteria in at least 2 studies lasting a minimum of 12 weeks. Program and control schools were equivalent at pretest in reading achievement. Posttest measures used must be valid standardized tests. Sample size of each study is important. The research-proven reading program must meet specific criteria in at least 2 studies lasting a minimum of 12 weeks. Sample size of each study is not less than 5 classes or 125 students per treatment. Median difference between program and control students must be at least 20 percent in favor of the program students. Department constitutes a review panel to determine qualifying programs. The Department establishes a review panel to determine which reading programs qualify as research-proven. Panel members must have expertise in scientific research and reading research, with no financial or personal connections to program authors or publishers. Panel meetings are open to the public, and minutes are made available. Title III defines a research-proven program.
